description: A widely cultivated creeping vine plant in the gourd family, Cucurbitaceae. It contains an edible fruit that is also called a cucumber. It is typically cylindrical, elongated with tapered ends, and may be as large as 60 centimeters long and 10 centimeters in diameter.
healthBenefits: Very high water content (about 95%), making it extremely hydrating.
Low in calories, beneficial for weight management.
May help freshen breath and soothe skin.

potentialAllergies.name: Cucurbitacin Sensitivity
potentialAllergies.details: Some cucumbers (especially wilder or stressed plants) can contain higher levels of cucurbitacins, causing bitterness and potentially digestive upset. Commercially grown cucumbers are usually bred for low bitterness.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Warm-season crop. Sow seeds directly after last frost or start indoors.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-7.0. Full sun.
3. Support: Vining varieties require a trellis or support; bush varieties are more compact.
4. Watering: Consistent and adequate watering is crucial, especially during flowering and fruiting.
5. Harvesting: Harvest when fruits are firm, smooth, and have reached the desired size for their variety, before they turn yellow or seeds harden. Harvest frequently.
growthDuration: 50-70 days from sowing to first harvest.
sustainabilityTips: Store cucumbers in the refrigerator crisper drawer for up to a week.
Peel if skin is waxy or tough, otherwise, the skin is edible and nutritious.
Use in salads, sandwiches, pickles, or infused water.
carbonFootprintInfo: Generally low (0.3-0.6 kg CO2e/kg) for field-grown. Greenhouse production, especially out of season, has a higher footprint.

staticRecipes.name: Refreshing Cucumber Salad
staticRecipes.description: A simple and crisp salad, perfect for summer.
ingredients: 2 tbsp rice vinegar or white wine vinegar
1 tbsp chopped fresh dill or parsley
steps: In a medium bowl, combine sliced cucumbers and red onion (if using).
In a small bowl, whisk together vinegar, sugar (if using), dill/parsley, salt, and pepper.
Pour the dressing over the cucumbers and toss gently to coat.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 15-30 minutes to allow flavors to meld. Serve chilled.

staticRecipes.name: Cucumber Raita (Yogurt Dip)
staticRecipes.description: A cooling Indian yogurt dip with grated cucumber and spices.
ingredients: Pinch of black salt (kala namak) or regular salt
1 tbsp chopped fresh cilantro or mint
Optional: a pinch of red chili powder for garnish
steps: Squeeze out excess water from the grated cucumber.
In a bowl, whisk yogurt until smooth.
Add grated cucumber, roasted cumin powder, salt, and chopped cilantro/mint to the yogurt. Mix well.
Chill for at least 30 minutes before serving.
Garnish with a sprinkle of red chili powder or a mint sprig if desired. Serve as a side with Indian meals.

staticRecipes.name: Quick Cucumber Pickles (Refrigerator Pickles)
staticRecipes.description: Crisp and tangy pickles that are easy to make and don't require canning.
ingredients: Optional: 1-2 cloves garlic (smashed), 1/2 tsp dill seeds or fresh dill sprigs, 1/4 tsp mustard seeds, pinch of red pepper flakes
steps: Pack sliced cucumbers tightly into a clean glass jar (or jars). Add garlic and other optional spices if using.
In a saucepan, combine vinegar, water, sugar, and salt. Bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring until sugar and salt dissolve completely.
Pour the hot brine over the cucumbers in the jar, ensuring they are fully submerged. Leave about 1/2 inch headspace.
Let cool to room temperature, then seal the jar and refrigerate. The pickles will be ready to eat in a few hours but are best after 24 hours.
Store in the refrigerator and consume within 2-3 weeks.

uses: Culinary (eaten raw in salads, sandwiches, appetizers; pickled; used in soups, gazpacho, tzatziki, raita)
Skincare (slices placed on eyes to reduce puffiness, in face masks)

climaticRequirements.temperature: Warm season crop. Optimal 18-30°C. Sensitive to frost. Requires full sun. High temperatures (>35°C) can reduce fruit quality.
climaticRequirements.rainfall: Prefers consistent moisture, around 25 mm per week during growing season. Good drainage is essential.
climaticRequirements.altitude: Best grown in lowlands and up to moderate altitudes.

soilPreferences: Well-drained, fertile loamy or sandy loam soils, rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-7.0. Avoids heavy clay or waterlogged soils.
irrigationWaterNeeds: Requires consistent and adequate moisture, especially during flowering and fruit development. Drip irrigation or soaker hoses are ideal to keep foliage dry and prevent diseases. Water stress can lead to bitter or misshapen fruit.
plantingHarvestCycles: Propagated by seeds, sown directly after last frost when soil is warm, or started indoors 3-4 weeks prior. Vining types require trellising or support; bush types are more compact. Pollination by bees is important for fruit set. Fruits are harvested when they reach desired size for the variety (slicing, pickling), are firm, and skin is smooth and green (before turning yellow). Harvest frequently (every 1-2 days) to encourage continuous production. Typically 50-70 days from sowing to first harvest.
pestDiseaseManagement: Pests: Cucumber beetles (striped and spotted), aphids, spider mites, squash bugs, squash vine borer, whiteflies. Diseases: Powdery mildew, downy mildew, angular leaf spot, anthracnose, cucumber mosaic virus (CMV), bacterial wilt (spread by cucumber beetles). Integrated pest management (IPM) includes resistant varieties, crop rotation, row covers, proper spacing for air circulation, sanitation, and targeted organic or chemical controls.
postHarvestHandling: Harvest by cutting the stem above the fruit. Handle carefully to avoid bruising. Store at cool temperatures (10-13°C) with high humidity (90-95%). Susceptible to chilling injury below 10°C (pitting, watery spots). Waxing may be used for some commercial varieties to reduce moisture loss. Shelf life is typically 1-2 weeks.
marketValueGlobalDemand: Very high global demand for fresh cucumbers (slicing and pickling types) and processed pickles. Significant international trade. Grown extensively in field and greenhouse operations. Prices vary by type, quality, season, and origin. Important for fresh markets, food service, and processing industries.
